thread.title: FFA Cup: ‘Suburban stars’ come out to play in knockout tournament | The
thread.title_full: FFA Cup: ‘Suburban stars’ come out to play in knockout tournament | The Advertiser

author: Carly Adno
title: FFA Cup: ‘Suburban stars’ come out to play in knockout tournament | The
text:
IT’S the competition that pits the amateurs against the professionals in a way no other sport is capable of doing, says FFA boss David Gallop, and that’s why football has such global appeal.
The second season of the FFA Cup starts Wednesday night, with matches taking place at suburban grounds across Sydney, Newcastle, the Gold Coast and Melbourne.
The likes of Real Madrid, Liverpool and Manchester City may have drawn record crowds to the biggest stadiums in the country, but this week Australian football “goes from the world to the suburbs”.
Palm Beach's Nikola Mirkovich will be in action against South Melbourne in the FFA Cup on Fox Sports. Pics Tim Marsden Source: News Corp Australia
“The launch of the FFA Cup shows just how diverse and appealing football can be on the back of the ICC tournament and Liverpool matches against Adelaide and Brisbane Roar,” Gallop said. “No other sport in Australia offers such a diversity of atmosphere and engagement where one week we have the biggest clubs in world football with stars like Cristiano Ronaldo and Raheem Sterling gracing our shores and the next week we have semi professional players mixing it with the likes of Melbourne Victory and Sydney FC. There are fans around Australia who will be equally excited about watching their grassroots club take on an A-League team at a suburban ground like Leichhardt Oval or ABD Stadium in Melbourne as they were watching Read Madrid and Manchester City in front of 100,000 fans in the biggest stadium in Australia.
“Football has once again shown that it is not only the football code that has true international appeal, but it is also the only sport that connects the grassroots with the professionals in a meaningful competition played in the country’s biggest stadiums as well as local grounds in the suburbs.”
Last week it was the powerhouses of Real Madrid and Manchester City, this week the ‘suburban stars’are on display. Source: Getty Images
In Sydney, the in form and experienced Blacktown City will host the Metrostars from South Australia at Lily’s Football Centre in Seven Hills.
But the eagerly awaited David against Goliath battles take place from next week, when the A-League clubs join in on the fun.
“Last year the FFA Cup brought the entire football community together like never before as David took on Goliath and we now eagerly look forward to seeing which clubs and players can write their names into FFA Cup folklore alongside the likes of Thomas Love, who knocked out the Wanderers and Bentleigh Greens,” Gallop said.
“The Magic of the Cup is back and it all starts on the Gold Coast, Melbourne, Sydney and Newcastle.”
WEDNESDAY’S ROUND OF 32
Palm Beach Sharks v South Melbourne (live on Fox Sports)
Blacktown City v Metrostars SC
Broadmeadow Magic v Heidelberg United FC
Hume City FC v Brisbane Strikers
 ‘Suburban stars’ come out to play in FFA Cup
